Our code HCT and =
a PSR code based on Chemkin both do this problem 
very well.  The key is to=
 specify an inlet boundary flux with each 
species concentration set to a d=
esired value, and an exit fixed 
pressure boundary.  Conceptually, this is =
easily done by using a 
premixed laminar flame set of boundary conditions, =
but collapsing the 
reaction zone of the flame into a single, therefore wel=
l mixed, 
reaction zone.  The inflow is given by specifying the fluxes of e=
ach 
species, and the exit is determinined by specifying the outlet 
pressu=
re.  In a sense, it's a homogeneous problem, but we compute it 
in a pseudo=
-1D formulation.

As your note suggests, the trick is the residence time.  =
The Chemkin 
PSR code does this elegantly, the HCT version does it by setti=
ng the 
pseudo-1D zone thickness so that the combination of the inlet flow =

velocity and the zone thickness produce an effective residence time. 
I ca=
n provide references if desired.

Charlie Westbrook
LLNL
